title: 2007 New Zealand rugby league season
text:
The 2007 New Zealand rugby league season was the 100th season of <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> that had been played in <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a>. The main feature of the year was the eighth season of the <a href="Bartercard%20Cup">Bartercard Cup</a> competition that was run by the <a href="New%20Zealand%20Rugby%20League">New Zealand Rugby League</a>. The <a href="Auckland%20Lions">Auckland Lions</a> won the Cup by defeating <a href="Harbour%20League">Harbour League</a> 28-4 in the Grand Final.
International competitions.
The <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">New Zealand national rugby league team</a> played one test match in New Zealand, losing to Australia. They then embarked on the <a href="2007%20All%20Golds%20Tour">2007 All Golds Tour</a> to celebrate the centenary of international rugby league. The touring squad was coached by <a href="Gary%20Kemble">Gary Kemble</a> and included: <a href="Louis%20Anderson">Louis Anderson</a>, captain <a href="Roy%20Asotasi">Roy Asotasi</a>, <a href="Luke%20Covell">Luke Covell</a>, <a href="Greg%20Eastwood">Greg Eastwood</a>, <a href="David%20Faiumu">David Faiumu</a>, <a href="Dene%20Halatau">Dene Halatau</a>, <a href="Shontayne%20Hape">Shontayne Hape</a>, <a href="Lance%20Hohaia">Lance Hohaia</a>, <a href="Krisnan%20Inu">Krisnan Inu</a>, <a href="Shaun%20Kenny-Dowall">Shaun Kenny-Dowall</a>, <a href="Epalahame%20Lauaki">Epalahame Lauaki</a>, <a href="Thomas%20Leuluai">Thomas Leuluai</a>, <a href="Jeff%20Lima">Jeff Lima</a>, <a href="Simon%20Mannering">Simon Mannering</a>, <a href="Steve%20Matai">Steve Matai</a>, <a href="Fuifui%20Moimoi">Fuifui Moimoi</a>, <a href="Sam%20Perrett">Sam Perrett</a>, <a href="Frank%20Pritchard">Frank Pritchard</a>, <a href="Sam%20Rapira">Sam Rapira</a>, <a href="Ben%20Roberts%20%28rugby%20league%29">Ben Roberts</a>, <a href="Jeremy%20Smith%20%28rugby%20league%20born%201981%29">Jeremy Smith</a>, <a href="Jeremy%20Smith%20%28rugby%20league%20born%201980%29">Jeremy Smith</a>, <a href="Chase%20Stanley">Chase Stanley</a>, <a href="Clinton%20Toopi">Clinton Toopi</a>, <a href="Taniela%20Tuiaki">Taniela Tuiaki</a>, <a href="Tame%20Tupou">Tame Tupou</a> and <a href="Paul%20Whatuira">Paul Whatuira</a>. In addition <a href="Nigel%20Vagana">Nigel Vagana</a>, <a href="Clinton%20Toopi">Clinton Toopi</a>, <a href="Stacey%20Jones">Stacey Jones</a>, <a href="Ruben%20Wiki">Ruben Wiki</a>, <a href="Steve%20Price%20%28rugby%20league%29">Steve Price</a>, <a href="Ali%20Lauitiiti">Ali Lauitiiti</a>, <a href="David%20Kidwell">David Kidwell</a>, <a href="Jason%20Cayless">Jason Cayless</a> and <a href="Awen%20Guttenbeil">Awen Guttenbeil</a> played for the All Golds in a celebration match. <a href="Wayne%20Bennett%20%28rugby%20league%29">Wayne Bennett</a> coached the All Golds side.
Earlier in the year the Kiwis had lost the <a href="ANZAC%20Test">ANZAC Test</a> 6-30. <a href="Jake%20Webster">Jake Webster</a>, <a href="Manu%20Vatuvei">Manu Vatuvei</a>, <a href="Benji%20Marshall">Benji Marshall</a>, <a href="Nathan%20Cayless">Nathan Cayless</a>, <a href="Sonny%20Bill%20Williams">Sonny Bill Williams</a>, <a href="Tony%20Puletua">Tony Puletua</a>, <a href="David%20Fa%27alogo">David Fa'alogo</a> and <a href="Iosia%20Soliola">Iosia Soliola</a> played in the ANZAC Test but did not tour at the end of the year.
The amateur <a href="Ireland%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Irish Wolfhounds</a> toured New Zealand in May–June, defeating <a href="Bay%20of%20Plenty%20rugby%20league%20team">Bay of Plenty</a> but losing to Whangarei Marists and Auckland Marists. They were coached by ex-pat <a href="Tony%20Benson%20%28rugby%20league%29">Tony Benson</a>.
National competitions.
Rugby League Cup.
The <a href="Hawke%27s%20Bay%20rugby%20league%20team">Hawke's Bay</a> defeated <a href="Gisborne-East%20Coast%20rugby%20league%20team">Gisborne Tairawhiti</a> 58-6 on 15 September 2007. <a href="Canterbury%20rugby%20league%20team">Canterbury B</a> then defeated the Hawke's Bay to win the <a href="Rugby%20League%20Cup">Rugby League Cup</a>. The <a href="Hawke%27s%20Bay%20Unicorns">Hawke's Bay Unicorns</a> included <a href="Elijah%20Niko">Elijah Niko</a>.
Bartercard Cup.
The 2007 season was the eighth and final season of the <a href="Bartercard%20Cup">Bartercard Cup</a> run by the <a href="New%20Zealand%20Rugby%20League">New Zealand Rugby League</a>. From 2008 onwards the NZRL was to revert to a <a href="Bartercard%20Premiership">more traditional provincial competition</a>.
There were no major team changes however the <a href="Tamaki%20Leopards">Tamaki Leopards</a> were renamed the <a href="Tamaki%20Titans">Tamaki Titans</a> and the <a href="Auckland%20Lions">Auckland Lions</a> also fielded a team in the <a href="NSWRL%20Premier%20League">NSWRL Premier League</a>. As a result, less players from the <a href="New%20Zealand%20Warriors">New Zealand Warriors</a> featured in the Bartercard Cup.
A Saturday double header took place each weekend with one game screened live on <a href="M%C4%81ori%20Television">Māori Television</a> and the other one delayed on a Sunday. This replaced 2006's Monday Night Football, a move welcomed by Canterbury Bulls head coach Brent Stuart. The double header was held at either <a href="Mt%20Smart%20Stadium">Mt Smart Stadium</a> or <a href="North%20Harbour%20Stadium">North Harbour Stadium</a> each weekend. There was only one Split Round (Round Eight over Queens Birthday Weekend) which meant the Grand Final was played in September.
The Playoffs.
The Bartercard Cup used the <a href="Page%20playoff%20system">Page-McIntyre system</a> in 2007. In the major semi-final at Waitemata Stadium, between the Auckland Lions and Harbour League the scores were tied at 40 all after normal time and 2 further periods of extra time. The game proceeded to go on for another 17 minutes and 16 seconds before Auckland finally scored the winning try. NZRL management believed that no game of rugby league has ever lasted that long, or at least certainly in modern times.
Provincial tour.
<a href="Auckland%20rugby%20league%20team">Auckland</a> conducted a <a href="Queen%27s%20Birthday">Queen's Birthday</a> weekend tour of the South Island. The team was coached by <a href="Sam%20Panapa">Sam Panapa</a>. The team defeated a <a href="West%20Coast%20rugby%20league%20team">West Coast Invitational XIII</a> 26-20 and <a href="Canterbury%20rugby%20league%20team">Canterbury</a> 28-24.
South Island Zone Competition.
The <a href="Southland%20rugby%20league%20team">Southland Rams</a>, <a href="Canterbury%20rugby%20league%20team">Canterbury B</a>, <a href="West%20Coast%20rugby%20league%20team">West Coast</a> and <a href="Otago%20rugby%20league%20team">Otago</a> played a four team tournament in September and October.
National Club Competition.
The <a href="Wainuiomata%20Lions">Wainuiomata Lions</a> defeated the <a href="Papakura%20Sea%20Eagles">Papakura Sea Eagles</a> 48-26 in the Grand Final of the National Club Competition. Wainuiomata defeated <a href="Manurewa%20Marlins">Manurewa</a> 40-18 in a semi final while Papakura defeated Kaiapoi 48-22.
Australian competitions.
The <a href="New%20Zealand%20Warriors">New Zealand Warriors</a> competed in the <a href="National%20Rugby%20League">National Rugby League</a> competition. They finished 4th out of 16 teams before losing to <a href="North%20Queensland%20Cowboys">North Queensland</a> in the Semi Finals.
The <a href="Auckland%20Lions">Auckland Lions</a> competed in the <a href="NSWRL%20Premier%20League">NSWRL Premier League</a> and finished 10th out of 13 teams.
Club competitions.
Auckland.
The <a href="Manurewa%20Marlins">Manurewa Marlins</a> won the Fox Memorial trophy, defeating the <a href="Papakura%20Sea%20Eagles">Papakura Sea Eagles</a> 28-20 in extra time in the grand final. Papakura had finished the season as minor premiers. <a href="Richmond%20Rovers">Richmond</a> won the Stormont Shield.
The <a href="Northcote%20Tigers">Northcote Tigers</a> won the Sharman Cup (Division Two) while <a href="Ponsonby%20Ponies">Ponsonby</a> won the Phelan Shield (Division Three).
Wellington.
The <a href="Wainuiomata%20Lions">Wainuiomata Lions</a> were coached by <a href="John%20Lomax%20%28rugby%20league%29">John Lomax</a>. <a href="David%20Lomax">David Lomax</a> stepped in as caretaker coach when his brother was unavailable.
The <a href="Wellington%20Rugby%20League">Wellington Rugby League</a> board was given full control of its own competition on 1 April after being "in review" by the <a href="New%20Zealand%20Rugby%20League">New Zealand Rugby League</a> since January 2003.
Canterbury.
Kaiapoi won the <a href="Canterbury%20Rugby%20League">Canterbury Rugby League</a> title.
Other Competitions.
The <a href="Taniwharau%20Rugby%20League%20Club">Taniwharau Rugby League Club</a> were the Waicoa Bay minor premiers and went on to win the grand final, defeating Turangawaewae. Taniwharau went through the season undefeated.
The Kia Ora Warriors defeated the Waitara Bears 29-20 in the Western Alliance grand final.
